intro: Heliophila arabidea, commonly known as the Arabian sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the Middle East and North Africa. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, typically during the warmer months. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires full sunlight to flourish. Heliophila arabidea is adapted to withstand drought conditions, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
